data.title: National Museum of Natural History – Museum Review
data.meta_description: Find National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., United States, ratings, photos, prices, expert advice, traveler reviews and tips, and more information from Condé Nast Traveler.
data.text:
Zoom out. What’s this place all about?

It’s impossible to miss the Smithsonian’s National Museum of Natural History. Set on the National Mall, this 1910 Beaux-Arts building with a soaring rotunda is one of the most visited museums in D.C.—and the world—bringing in 4.2 million visitors in 2019. That’s for good reason: this museum has the world’s largest natural history collection with 146 million artifacts and specimens. The museum awes visitors from the second they walk in thanks to the 13-foot-tall African elephant watching over the rotunda. (His name is Henry.)

What will we find in the permanent collection?

You might think it’d be hard to know where to begin, but that question is actually easy: Start with the dinosaurs. In 2019, the museum reopened its beloved dinosaur and fossil hall after undertaking the most extensive renovation in its history. In the new "Deep Time" exhibit, you’ll travel back in time to the Jurassic Era and beyond. T Rex and Triceratops fossils tower over you while you learn about geological events of the past, compare the effects of climate change then and now, and discover how microbes created the world as we know it.But there’s so much to see beyond fossil hall. The National Museum of Natural History is home to the Hope Diamond, early human artifacts, Ancient Egyptian mummies, and a butterfly pavilion. You can also explore ocean life and mammal habitats or learn about the diversity of African cultures. And while the museum takes a wide lens on the natural world, there’s impressive depth to each exhibit—not to mention opportunities to connect what you’re learning to your own experiences.

And what kind of temporary exhibits come through?

Temporary exhibitions are just as sensational and educational as the permanent collection, whether you’re learning about narwhals or researching infectious diseases. Throughout the museum, you’ll also get opportunities to experience what you’re learning or watch real scientists in action.

What did you make of the crowd?

Expect them. This is a hot spot for families and school trips—nothing animates children like dinosaur bones and giant whale replicas—but the flow moves fairly quickly.

On the practical tip, how were the facilities?

It can be a little intimidating to get around this 325,000-square-foot museum. Maps are available for a small fee and it’s worth grabbing one (or checking the online version) to figure out a game plan.

Any guided tours worth trying?

There aren’t any regular tours, but volunteer interpreters are stationed at exhibitions at various times of the day.

Whats for sale in the gift shop?

There are several gift shops—including a gem and mineral store and a mammal store located conveniently near the relevant exhibits—full of educational toys, stuffed animals, apparel, jewelry, books, and science kits.

Is the café worth a stop, or should we just plan on going elsewhere?

Choose between two cafés: The Atrium Café offers standards like pizza, burgers, sandwiches, and chicken tenders; the Ocean Terrace Café focuses on salads and grain bowls.

Any advice for the time- or attention-challenged?

You could spend a full day here and still feel like you need more time. But if you’re in a hurry, start with the Deep Time dinosaur exhibit then head upstairs to scope out the Hope Diamond or the Butterfly Pavilion. You have to buy a ticket to enter the latter, but it’ll be worth it when you’re making friends with one of the hundreds of butterflies.
